answers.answer: Hi Pacecar,Your child is having recurrent abdominal pain. In most of the cases, it is just functional and you dont find any cause. But functional pain does not cause weight loss. But since your child is having weight loss, it cant be a functional pain.The problems you have mentioned are quite diverse. So I am not able to give any direct answer for this.But still you can consider -1. Inflammatory bowel disease2. Celiac disease3. Infectious causeDiscuss with your gastro regarding these.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The information provided is for patients’ education only and is not a medical advice. Always consult your personal physician for complete evaluation of your health problem.- Ratnakar Kini M.D.

question: My  8 yoS as been having mod. to sev. pain located at the periumbilical area.  1st mention of the pain appros. 1 yr ago.  At T-giving it became worse.  We've seen a Ped. Gastro, had endoscopy w/biopsies, contrast. CT, Ultrasound, Xrays and bloodwork.   Nothing showed up except C-diff and some minor swelling of his messiatic lymphnodes.   We were put on Nexium (am), Zantac (pm), Bentyl, and Anilan.  We've had a HIDA Scan that showed 0% function of the g'bladder but no pain during test.  Ped. Surgeon didn't think it was G-bladder because Bentyl can give false posit.  Finally they gave us Demerol to control pain but we are not crazy about cont' use of this.  Dr said possible food allergy.Past few days pain has slowed to only after meals & every night when  he lays down.   The pain is intense & last approx 1 - 4 hours after onset. Other things that might be helpful.   Our son has alway had some Gastro probs since birth.  He had refulx at an early age & outgrew it, always been easy to constipate. He has a bi-cuspid aorta - never caused a problem & only noticed as a murmur or if he is very sick or taking lots of meds he will get the blueing around the lips.   We have seen this blueing lately. In August we began taking Strattera for ADHD and he's adj. well.  We consid. the Strattera as a culprit but the pain began before taking it. Few symptoms we've seen over the past year that we passed off as nothing & now started re-thinking them.   Headaches, joint pain w/knees & ankles.  Numbness & tingling in the feet & legs.   Pain between the shoulders.   Always seems to  be thirsty & seems to get hungry really quickly after eating.   We asked to check. for diabetes & our primary dr said that has always been w/in normal range.   He doesn't have a very good appetite & he has lost about 3 lbs since T-giving.So ANY insite would be wonderful.There are prob. other things we could test for but we just don't know what to ask.   Txs So much!
title: Frustrated Parents!
